intro: Sisymbrium runcinatum, commonly known as the narrowleaf mustards, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender, branching stems and small, greenish-yellow flowers that bloom from June to August. The plant has pinnately compound leaves with serrated edges and produces small, round pods that contain several seeds. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in fields, roadsides, and along riverbanks. Sisymbrium runcinatum is known for its rapid growth and ability to colonize open areas, making it a common weed in agricultural settings.
